awd_titl_txt: Coastal SEES: developing new modeling tools to predict ocean acidification impacts on coastal ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
An immediate consequence of the dissolution of CO2 in seawater is an increase in the acidity of the water, which has implications for organisms that rely on carbonate chemistry for vital functions. As the occurrence of lower pH and lower oxygen events along the U.S. west coast is likely to increase in frequency and worsen in magnitude over the next decades, it is paramount to carefully document present-day variability in water column pH and oxygen associated with seasonal and interannual changes in coastal upwelling, and produce reference pH and oxygen fields at the spatial (kilometers) and temporal (days) scales needed to assess their impact on ecosystem processes. To address this need, the proposed research uses a state-of-the art, data-assimilative, coupled physical-biogeochemical modeling framework to quantify the temporal variability of low pH and low oxygen intrusions along central California at the spatial scales relevant to coastal ecosystems. In addition, the modelling effort relies on an ensemble approach to identify the degree of certainty with which the frequency of occurrence and duration of low pH and low oxygen events can be predicted on daily to seasonal timescales, a critical component for improving future management strategies designed to mitigate the effects of ocean acidification on marine organisms. It is also anticipated that the results will apply to other eastern boundary current upwelling systems and improve broader knowledge of coastal upwelling impacts on biogeochemical processes (e.g., the long-term sign and magnitude of nearshore air-sea CO2 fluxes). The study will contribute to training a new generation of scientists versed in multidisciplinary ocean science and management concepts. Specifically, it will provide training for two post-doctoral researchers and one graduate student in (1) coupled physical-biogeochemical data assimilation, (2) regional-to-local downscaling of model simulations, (3) interpretation of complex numerical model solutions, and (4) creation of products targeted at improving resource management in the face of ocean acidification. In addition, the lead PI will give general audience lectures on the use of models and observations to study ocean acidification along the California coast.

Because the significant amount of variability occurring over relatively short spatial (< 100 km) and temporal (days to weeks) scales presents a challenge for coastal ocean observing systems and monitoring programs, the routine use of data-assimilative physical-biogeochemical models would greatly enhance current capabilities for predicting the occurrence of low pH and low oxygen events off central California. In this regard, this research has the following short- and long-term benefits: (1) establish the connections between alongshore upwelling variability and the frequency, magnitude and duration of low pH and low oxygen conditions on the shelf, (2) examine the probability that certain pH and oxygen thresholds below which conditions become detrimental to key marine organisms are exceeded for extended periods, (3) guide the implementation of an efficient monitoring system network by identifying specific regions where pH and oxygen variability is expected to be largest, and (4) implement a modeling framework capable of predicting the occurrence of extreme low pH and low oxygen events off central California, and assess its usefulness for decision-making purposes. These developments contribute to Coastal SEES overarching objectives of advancing understanding of fundamental, interconnected processes in coastal systems on a variety of spatial and temporal scales, improving capabilities for predicting future coastal system states and impacts, and identifying pathways by which research results will be translated to policy and management domains and used to enhance coastal sustainability.

por.por_cntn:
Ocean acidification and hypoxia result from decreasing pH and oxygen levels in the ocean in response to global climate change and pose an important threat to marine organisms worldwide and the communities that depend on them. Along the U.S. west coast, these impacts are expected to be particularly severe because the region exhibits naturally lower pH and oxygen conditions. Every year, strong winds blow parallel to the coast and bring cold, nutrient-laden deep water close to the surface (a process called "coastal upwelling") fueling important plankton blooms and supporting a rich and diverse ecosystem. These deep waters are also naturally more acidified and contain less oxygen than surface waters. As pH and oxygen levels are expected to further decrease as human emissions of CO2 continues through the 21st century, it is critical to improve our understanding of how often and for how long marine organisms along the U.S. west coast will be exposed to detrimental pH and oxygen conditions. Our project focused on two important themes: (1) describe the physical and biological mechanisms that control nearshore pH and oxygen conditions at spatial scales matching local ecosystem variability, and (2) implement new data assimilation tools to improve model predictions of ocean acidification and hypoxia.

To study how marine organisms have been exposed to low pH and low oxygen along the U.S. west coast in the last 30 years, we have developed computer models capable of simulating the ecosystem response to local and regional circulation patterns and coastal upwelling. We found that low pH and low oxygen "hotspots" occur locally near coastal promontories, such as capes, where upwelling is more intense. We also established that meanders of the California Current (the major ocean current flowing along the U.S. west coast) affect upwelling efficiency, and nearshore regions where currents curve toward the coast undergo less severe low pH and low oxygen conditions. Using established thresholds for detrimental pH and oxygen effects on marine organisms, we explored which physical and biological mechanisms determine how frequently conditions drop below these thresholds, and for how long, on a weekly, seasonal, and multi-year basis. Our results indicate that, along central and northern California, low oxygen events have not historically occurred, but that low pH events have been seasonally affecting a significant fraction of the coastline over the past 30 years. The severity of low pH events depends primarily on the properties of the deep waters being upwelled near the coast and is exacerbated during years when pH is naturally lower and at nearshore locations where recycling of plankton biomass at depth further lowers pH in upwelled waters. We have also generated high-resolution climate projections that will allow us to understand how these low pH and low oxygen conditions will evolve over the course of the 21st century and affect marine ecosystems along the U.S. west coast. So far, our results have been shared through scientific publications and contributed to a report for the California Department of Fish and Wildlife, Ocean Protection Council and Sea Grant highlighting changes in pH and oxygen near marine protected areas. We are also working on a web-based application that will allow resource managers to visualize the projected evolution of ocean acidification in the region, as well as the reliability of these projections at the local and regional scales relevant to coastal marine ecosystems along central and northern California.

The accuracy of ocean circulation and ecosystem model solutions can be improved through a numerical technique called "data assimilation" that corrects simulated variables using information from real-world observations. While the assimilation of physical observations (temperature, for example) is relatively routine, integrating biological and chemical observations (oxygen and pH, for example) into marine ecosystem models is more challenging and complicated by the fact that these observations have limited spatial and temporal coverage and may not correspond directly to variables represented by the model. Our research has contributed to advancing the numerical techniques available for assimilating biological and chemical observations into marine ecosystem models by rigorously testing improvements to model accuracy resulting from various measurement types and by widening the range of observations that can be used to correct model solutions. We focused our efforts on understanding to what extent currently available biological and chemical measurements can improve the accuracy of short-term (days to weeks) forecasts of low pH and low oxygen conditions. Our results demonstrate that, while the new data assimilation techniques developed during the project work and help improve biological and chemical predictions locally, there is not at present a sufficient network of observations to improve predictions related to ocean acidification and hypoxia at the scale of an entire region such as the California Current.
